The first lies directly beneath the skin, while the latter surrounds the organs and is perhaps the most harmful. ğŸ’š RESULTS.results_paragraph5: It is also essential to understand that our body and its functioning are the result of evolution. Everything has been organized to have available and stored energy. It is therefore fundamental to understand that our body responds to biochemical processes and efficient physiology in how stored energy is used. The main source of energy comes from food, and any excess will be stored rather than lost.
ğŸ’š RESULTS.results_paragraph6: In simple terms, excess energy becomes body fatâ€”adipose tissue made up of adipocytes, specialized cells that can increase in size and number. Fat is not 'burned'; rather, it is beta-oxidized in the mitochondria found in nearly all cells. Weight gain is a gradual process where adipocytes store triglycerides. When we lose weight, lipolysis occurs: triglycerides break down and release fatty acids into the bloodstream, which are then used by cells to produce energy (ATP) within mitochondria.
ğŸ’š RESULTS.results_paragraph7: We must also be clear that we do not gain weight overnight; it is a gradual process in which adipocytes store triglycerides, composed of one glycerol molecule and three fatty acids. When we want to lose weight, lipolysis should occur: the triglyceride bond breaks, releasing fatty acids into the bloodstream. These travel to cells in tissues that need energy, enter the mitochondria, and generate the energy molecule known as ATP.
